markdownRemark.html:
Java language gives us two ways to check whether objects are equal. We can use either == operator or equals() method.

== operator:

  • if used for primitive types compares its values,
  • if used for objects compares its by references (so no two objects are equal).

equals() method:

  • if not overridden (default implementation is form Object class) works like == operator (compares objects references),
  • if overridden - it depends…

Problem

Sometimes we want to treat two objects as equal by some of it’s attributes. To achieve this, we need to override equals() method for its class. Doing this properly is not trivial task and lot of things may go wrong.

Solution

In most cases, default equality behaviour is fine and reasonable. Overriding equals() makes sense in objects which represents data structures, because we may want to compare them by its properties.

Properly overridden equals() method should fulfill contract:

  • reflexivity: x.equals(x) == true
  • symmetry: x.equals(y) == y.equals(x)
  • transitivity: x.equals(y)
